thread.title: Nigel Farage spotted 'gatecrashing' dinner with Donald Trump in President's Washington DC hotel
thread.title_full: Nigel Farage spotted 'gatecrashing' dinner with Donald Trump in President's Washington DC hotel

author: Mikey Smith
title: Nigel Farage spotted 'gatecrashing' dinner with Donald Trump in President's Washington DC hotel
text:
Nigel Farage spotted 'gatecrashing' dinner with Donald Trump in President's Washington DC hotel Onlookers said the ex-Ukip leader "wasn't invited" but was squeezed in "last minute" Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Nigel Farage was spotted dining with Donald Trump last night in the President's Washington DC Hotel. 
Onlookers said the ex-Ukip leader "wasn't invited" to the soiree, but was squeezed in "last minute". 
Farage was snapped enjoying a meal with the president, his daughter Ivanka , son-in-law Jared Kushner and Florida governor Rick Scott. 
Meanwhile, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson was reportedly sitting on the other side of the restaurant, having dinner with his wife. 
The group was spotted by journalist Benny Johnson, who said the Secret Service "swarmed the place" before Trump and co swanned in for a bite. Read More 
He tweeted: "Farage was not invited to this dinner. Squeezed in last second." 
Earlier in the evening, Farage's publicist tweeted that he was watching Aston Villa in the Hotel's bar. 
After dinner, Johnson approached Trump to ask whether he'd be attending the White House Correspondents' dinner. 
Trump replied: "No. Do you like that?" 
Last night, Trump tweeted to say he was chickening out of the annual 'nerd prom' - a gala dinner during which comedians frequently poke fun at the President. 
He'll be the first president to avoid the roasting since Ronald Reagan in 1981, who didn't turn up because he was recovering an assassination attempt. 
Trump’s luxury DC hotel is in the city’s old post office building, which is still owned by the Federal Government. 
The legitimacy of Trump’s lease on the property, which opened the month before November’s general election, have been called into question, after it emerged the terms prohibit office holders of being involved. 
There have also been questions about whether foreign dignitaries staying at the hotel would constitute a breach of the US constitutions emoluments clause, which bans office holders gaining profits from overseas. Like us on Facebook
